persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

places.name: Arabian Peninsula
places.description: a peninsula in West Asia, situated northeast of Africa on the Arabian Plate. It includes the territories of includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, as well as southern Iraq and Jordan. In the classical era, the Sinai Peninsula was also considered a part of Arabia.

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: John JoachimBecher
persons.description: German physician and alchemist. Davy gives him incorrect dates in notebook 15E.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
persons.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

persons.name: Torbern OlafBergman
persons.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: WilliamHarvey
persons.description: Physician who discovered the circulation of the blood.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: WilliamGilbert
persons.description: English physician, man of science, and author of the influential treatise De Magnete (1600).

persons.name: Otto deGuericke
persons.description: German man of science, politican and inventor, who invented the first air pump and showed the power of a vacuum.

persons.name: BenjaminFranklin
persons.description: Man of science born in Philadelphia. Inventor, printer, publisher, political philosopher, and a Founding Father of the United States. FRSL.

persons.name: FrancisHauksbee
persons.description: English natural philosopher best known for his work on electricity and electrostatic repulsion. FRSL

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

places.name: Bologna
places.description: A city in and the capital of the Emilia-Romagna region in Northern Italy, of which it is also its largest.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
persons.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: AbrahamBennet
persons.description: Natural philosopher and close associate with Priestley, Darwin and Wedgwood. He recorded atmospheric electricity. FRSL.

persons.name: Johann WilhelmRitter
persons.description: German physician and natural philosopher.

persons.name: EdwardAsh
persons.description: Oxford trained physician and a friend of Rumford's whom he met in Italy. An Annual Subscriber to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: Giovanni Valentino MattiaFabbroni
persons.description: Italian naturalist, economist, agronomist and chemist.

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: LuigiGalvani
persons.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

persons.name: Carl CasparCreve
persons.description: Professor of medicine at Mainz.

persons.name: Johann GeorgSulzer
persons.description: Swiss mathematician who later worked in Berlin on electricity and also translated Hume into German.

persons.name: EdwardNairne
persons.description: Possibly the most well known scientific instrument maker of his time. Worked closely with Franklin, Priestley and Cavendish. 'Nairne's Machine' referred to his patented electrostatic generator, which was intended to treat a variety of medicinal ailments via electrical shocks. FRSL.

persons.name: Franz Ulrich TheodorAepinus
persons.description: German born natural philosopher who mostly worked in Russia. Best known for his researches, theoretical and experimental, in electricity and magnetism.
